author: Joanna Mather
title: Negative gearing, super tax reform 'sensible', says Nick Greiner
text:
Outspoken former NSW premier Nick Greiner says negative gearing changes could be part of a 'sensible' reform package Photo: Jessica Hromas by Joanna Mather Liberal Party stalwart Nick Greiner says changes to superannuation tax concessions and negative gearing could form part of a "sensible" reform package.
The former NSW premier said it was probably worth looking at tax benefits flowing to superannuation and some changes to negative gearing "but not its elimination".
Mr Greiner and former Victorian premier John Brumby led the last major review of the GST, which focused predominantly on the distribution of revenue raised by the tax.
A final report in 2011 did not recommend an overhaul of of the system in the short term, but advised the then Labor government to reduce the $1000 GST free threshold for online imports.
This has not yet occurred, although Treasurer Joe Hockey has said he will push for the change when he meets state and territory finance ministers next month.
Mr Greiner backs an increase to the GST.
" I actually think the GST ought to go up and frankly also does every person considered an expert," he told the ABC in late 2014.
"There is no one who thinks the opposite, either in Australia or outside. It is an efficient and effective tax."
